statement.tex: \text{Given that E and F are events such that}\newline P(E)=0.6, P(F)=0.3 \text{ and } P(E\cap F)=0.2, \newline \text{find } P(E|F) \text{ and } P(F|E).

step.tex: P(E\cap F) = \text{Probability that E and F }\newline \text{ both happen }
P(E\cap F) = \text{Probability that either E or F }\newline \text{ happen }
P(E|F) = \text{Probability that E happens given that F }\newline \text{ already happened }
P(E|F) = \text{Probability that E happens given that F }\newline \text{ did not happen }
step.reason: P(E|F) \text{indicates the probability that E will happen }\newline \text{ given that F already took place }

step.context: \text{How are } P(E|F) \text{ and } F(E\cap F) \text{ related ?}
step.reason: \text{Intuitively, if occurence of F is a certainity }\newline \text{ than it makes sense that the probability that both}\newline \text{ must occur is the ratio} P(E\cap E) \text{:} P(E)
